Award.AwardTitle: CDI Type II: Cyber-Enabled Understanding of Complexity in Socio-Ecological Systems via Computational Thinking

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance understanding of complexity in climate-societal dynamics by applying cyber-enabled multiagent systems models integrated with evolutionary computation algorithms. The research will develop, validate, and analyze new computational agent-based models as transformative tools for simulating human societies spatially situated in regions with diverse ecosystems and explicit climate dynamics. The new suite of models will focus on two geographic regions where climate change has significant consequences for humans and ecosystems: Sub-Saharan Africa (over a billion people at high risk of displacement, disease, starvation) and the Arctic Circumboreal region (where the fastest ecological changes are now occurring with shifting patterns comparable to earlier major climate events).

The project forges interdisciplinary collaboration among anthropologists, political scientists, earth scientists, and computer scientists to advance the science of complex adaptive systems. The core intellectual merit of the project is its contribution to basic understanding of multiscale complexity in climate-society dynamics, by creating a cyber-enabled integrated computational framework for modeling, simulating, and exploring scenarios. Spatial multiagent systems will be created that include climate dynamics as well as other natural hazards and stressors with direct and indirect effects on social dynamics composed of households and governance institutions.

Broader impacts from this project will include (1) new cross-disciplinary understanding of climate-society dynamics, (2) new computational tools; (3) new policy-relevant insights derived via scenario analysis with such tools; (4) innovations in new advanced forms of hybrid computational modeling, enabling new collaborations across disciplines; (5) new support for innovative forms of teaching, training, and learning through computational modeling of complex socio-ecological systems; (6) and multi-institutional opportunities for students from underrepresented groups via classroom visits and museum exhibits. Perpetual archiving of all electronic materials (code and data) will be implemented through the Smithsonian data archiving initiative.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This innovative international and interdisciplinary science project led by the Mason Center for Social Complexity, in cooperation with the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History, investigated the effects of environmental changes on human populations located in geographically extensive and complex regions of the globe, specifically the northern boreal and Arctic regions, as well as the South American Andean region. The project was supported by the National Science Foundation's Cyber-enabled Discoveries and Innovation (CDI) Program, which focuses on generating innovative scientific knowledge through the medium of advanced computing. Scientists from many fields of STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) participated in this investigation, utilizing historical and environmental data, scientific theories, and diverse methodologies, such as agent-based modeling, evolutionary computation, ethnographic field surveys, and geospatial tools, among others. Some of the investigators involved included natural scientists, social scientists, and computational scientists, with specializations in disciplines such climatology, anthropology, political science, human geography, computer science, cognitive science, and applied mathematics.

  While the complexity of these vast regions is caused by numerous features (large number of entities and components, dynamic interactions, unpredictable and nonintuitive effects, among others), investigators were nonetheless able to produce innovative advances, thanks to the convergence of theories, methodologies, and technologies from each of the pertinent domains. For example, a major product of this project was the creation of a data-calibrated, verified, and validated computer model that integrated the natural, the social, and the built environments in the northern part of the Earth's globe covering from approximately forty degrees north all the way up to the North Pole; in other words, the world's northern regions where most economic activity is located. A separate important result was also the creation of a similar computer model for a region of the Andes located in Peru (Huancayo region), where glaciers are melting and infrastructure systems and local populations (society, economy, and politics) are adversely affected. The creation of complex but insightful computational models in two regions that are so different in natural, social, and engineering features was a demonstration of the versatility of the convergent science and technology of complex adaptive systems being advanced by this project through closely coordinated and integrative interdisciplinary investigation.

  An unexpected product of this project was the creation of a novel mathematical tool for more accurately analyzing and understanding the properties of complex systems that contain both continuous and discrete features. These hybrid systems are common in coupled natural-human-engineered systems, such as those existing in the northern boral and Arctic regions, so the new mathematical tool (a new calculus operator called "nabladot") promises to provide new exact results for detailed analyses that have been previously approximated by coarse methods. Initial presentations of the new operator to separate computer science and mathematics audiences have thus far been encouraging. Several challenging areas of application are being identified for in-depth analysis using the new operator. While mathematical in nature, the new operator is best analyzed computationally, due to the analytical complexity of the mathematics involved, so it represents another form of cyber-enabled innovation – the main goal and purpose of the CDI Program grant that enabled this project.

 A large number of early career junior faculty, postdocs, and graduate students participated in this five-year project, several of them graduating with Ph.D. degrees from George Mason University in fields such as computational social science, climatology, and computer science – another strategic result supportive of and implementing the NSF's CDI program. Computational social science, in particular, is a fledging field with a bright future for meeting the challenges of understanding social complexity when coupled with natural and infrastructure systems in contemporary civilization. While all faculty and senior investigators continue at their respective academic institutions, all students and most postdocs have moved on to new and exciting positions in government, academia, and private industry.

  The northern boreal region and the Arctic are currently experiencing significant net immigrations originating from southern regions. These are among the most complex, consequential, and long-term processes that take place in coupled human-environmental systems, requiring applied computational science to understand and hopefully improve resilience and sustainability. While some negative effects are identified in some of the results of our project (such as increased urbanization and population densities beyond the design or planning assumptions of contemporary urban areas and settlement systems, causing additional demands on insufficient and ill-maintained infrastructure systems), other results point toward new prospects and opportunities for human activities in areas previously less desirable for human habitation (such as the northermost latitudes of  boreal regions and the Arctic itself; confirming the so-called "greening of the Arctic" effect). The future will likely unfold in ways not exactly anticipated by our models, but models such as those generated by this project can help illuminate alternative future scenarios, assisting decision-makers in planning for improvements and mitigating risks, based on more advanced scientific understanding.
